help-doc.title: WebGenome Help

section.title: WebGenome Version 2.3 Overview
section.p: WebGenome is a web-based application for creating genomics plots of array-based data and genomic annotation. This version provides a client plotting service to external applications, such as Rembrandt. Users must enter webGenome through redirection from another application; the only way to load data is by selecting it in the application client.
Data types supported in this version include copy number (i.e., aCGH), loss of heterozygosity (LOH), and gene expression. Two basic types of plots can be generated:

prop-list.prop: Plots DNA copy number measurements across the genome, chromosome, or chromosomal interval.
Shows chromosomal amplifications and deletions in relation to cytogenetic chromosome ideograms.

section.p: The underlying data model used by webGenome is a very simplied version of the MAGE-OM. The most important concept for the use of the system is that individual array data sets, called bioassays are aggregated into experiments.

section.title: Shopping Cart
section.p: The shopping cart accumulates raw data sets loaded by the client application, statistically processed data sets derived from raw or other processed data, and plots generated. For each experiment, the list of nested bioassays is also shown. Users may change the names of experiments and bioassays in this screen. Names do not have to be unique and can be empty if desired. Users may delete experiments and plots.

Each bioassay has an associated color. These colors are used in scatter plots to distinguish between bioassays. Colors are initialized by the system. Users may change colors and all future plots will use the new colors. However, previously-generated plots in the cart will retain the original colors.
From the shopping cart users may select one or more experiments and generate new plots or perform analytic operations. New plots and statistically processed experiments are saved back into the cart.

help-doc.section:
In this section we describe plotting functionality including the types of plots that can be generated and plotting parameters that can be set by the user. Functionality to create new plots is accessible from the shopping cart screen.
WebGenome 2.3 includes two plot types: scatter plots and ideogram plots.
Scatter plots display array reporter values (e.g. copy number) against physical genome location. Users can plot data points, regression lines, and confidence intervals in these plots. If data are loss of heterozygosity (LOH), then the endpoints are LOH regions are inferred and shown as thick horizontal lines. The Y-coordinate of these lines are equal to the average probability of LOH weighted by the chromosomal distance between adjacent reporters.
Scatter plots provide basic interactivity. Clicking on a data point causes all data points and lines from the bioassay to be highlighted. Also the bioassay name in the plot legend will be outlined. Moving the mouse across the plot will cause a tool tip to indicate the nearest reporters. If available, nearby genes will also be displayed along with arbitrary annotation that may be available through the client application.
This plot shows color-coded data values in relation to chromosome ideograms. The color coding goes from green to blue to red, which indicates data values that are low, medium, and high, respectively. Moving the mouse over ideograms causes a tool tip to indicate the cytoband and physical chromosomal location under the pointer. Moving the mouse over data tracks causes a tool tip to indicate the physical chromosomal interval and data value under the points. If available nearby genes will also be displayed along with arbitrary annotation that may be available through the client application.
Plotting parameters control how data will be presented graphically. There are parameters that are common to all plot types, such as genome intervals, and parameters specific to one type of plot. After the user elects to create a new plot from the shopping cart, a form showing parameters for the selected plot type is displayed. The user may later change these parameter settings by clicking on a link above displayed plots. Descriptions of the various parameters are given here.
These parameters are common to all plots.
This parameter enables the user to name the plot. This name need not be unique and can be changed at any time with no harm.
This parameter constrains the genome interval that will be displayed in plots. Genome segments should be specified in the following format: CHROMOSOME[:FROM-TO][,CHROMOSOME[:FROM-TO]]*
Examples
3:40000-50000
3,5:140000-160000
1,2
1:5000-7000,2:30000-100000
When the user specifies multiple genome intervals, they will be displayed in different plots, which will be laid out in rows. This parameter specifies how many plots will be in a row.
The following parameters are specific to scatter plots.
Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) data may be expressed as probability of LOH. This parameter is a threshold, above which probabilities will be interpred as indicative of LOH.
This parameter is only applicable if the data are LOH (loss of heterozygosity). Scatter plots of LOH indicate LOH regions as thick horizontal lines. If for two adjacent reporters one is measuring LOH and the other is not, the location where the transition occurs cannot be known. If this parameter is checked, the system will interpolate the LOH endpoint using the slope of a straight line between data points corresponding to the two reporters. If unchecked, the endpoint will be at the LOH reporter.
This parameter is only applicable if the data are LOH (loss of heterozygosity). Scatter plots of LOH indicate LOH regions as thick horizontal lines. If this parameter is checked, then the underlying raw LOH probabilites are also plotted.
This sets the minimum value on the scatter plot Y-axis.
This sets the maximum value on the scatter plot Y-axis.
This sets the width of each individual scatter plot in pixels. If multiple genome intervals are selected, the this propery applies to each of the corresponding plots.
This sets the height of each individual scatter plot in pixels. If multiple genome intervals are selected, the this propery applies to each of the corresponding plots.
If checked, horizontal grid lines emenating from the major tic marks on the Y-axis will be drawn across scatter plot.
If checked, vertical grid lines emenating from the major tic marks on the X-axis will be drawn across scatter plot.
If checked, indivdual data points will be painted for each datum.
The averaging analytic operation also calculates standard error values. If plotting averages in a scatter plot, if this is checked then error bars will be painted for each data point.
If checked, "regression lines" connecting adjacent data points will be painted.
The following parameters are specific to ideogram plots.
This enables the user to set the relative height of chromosome ideograms.
This specifies the width of chromosome ideograms in pixels.
This specifies the width of data tracks in pixels.
Background data values within a range (e.g., -0.2 and 0.3) can be masked so that only regions of significant magnitudes are colored. This parameter is the the lower end of this range.
Background data values within a range (e.g., -0.2 and 0.3) can be masked so that only regions of significant magnitudes are colored. This parameter is the the upper end of this range.
Data tracks color code measured values (e.g. copy number) from green to blue to red. These colors correspond to low, medium, and high values, respectively. The saturation values indicate which values are mapped to pure green or red. Values below and above the saturation points are mapped to pure green and red, respectively. This parameter is for the lower saturation value.
Data tracks color code measured values (e.g. copy number) from green to blue to red. These colors correspond to low, medium, and high values, respectively. The saturation values indicate which values are mapped to pure green or red. Values below and above the saturation points are mapped to pure green and red, respectively. This parameter is for the upper saturation value.

prop-list.prop: This operation invokes the aCGH hidden Markov model-based method from the Bioconductor software package to smooth data.
This operation performs chromosome position-wise averaging of all data points within the same experiment.

This operation filters out all data with values between two endpoints. The upper and lower endpoints may be INFINITY or -INFINITY, respectively. This is used primarily for removing outliers. This operation includes the following parameters:
Lower filter endpoint
Upper filter endpoint

This operation subtracts the bioassay specific mean or median from each observation. The user specifies the use of the mean or median as the normalization factor. The choice of median based normalization allows the user to lessen the effect of outliers. This type of normalization is useful for making spot intensities comparable across arrays as it removes an overall array effect; each array will be "centered" on zero (or something close to it if the median is used).

This procedure subtracts the array specific mean or median from each observation then adds the experiment level mean or median back to each observation. The user specifies the use of the mean or median as the normalization factor. The choice of median based normalization allows the user to lessen the effect of outliers. This type of normalization is useful for making spot intensities comparable across arrays while preserving any overall difference due to treatment effect. This will center each array on the difference between it's own array mean/median and the experiment wide mean/median.

This operation smooths data using a "sliding window" approach. The user specified a Window size. The value of probe i is equal to the average value of probes i - w/2 through i + w/2, where w is the size of the window.

This operation identifies the set of common alteration across bioassays. These alterations are defined by a threshold and a minPercent property. The threshold is used for scoring alterations. For instance, if the threshold is set to 0.5, then all LOH probability values greater than this value will be considered LOH. The minPercent propety defines the minimum percentage of bioassays that must contain an alteration at a particular location for the alteration to be considered common.
